review.title: Leveraging Node Attributes for Incomplete Relational Data
review.abstract: Relational data are usually highly incomplete in practice, which inspires us to leverage side information to improve the performance of community detection and link prediction. This paper presents a Bayesian probabilistic approach that incorporates various kinds of node attributes encoded in binary form in relational models with Poisson likelihood. Our method works flexibly with both directed and undirected relational networks. The inference can be done by efficient Gibbs sampling which leverages sparsity of both networks and node attributes. Extensive experiments show that our models achieve the state-of-the-art link prediction results, especially with highly incomplete relational data.

metadata.title: Leveraging Node Attributes for Incomplete Relational Data

sections.heading: 2.2. The Asymmetric Node Attribute Relational Model
sections.text: In Extension of Beta-Gamma-Gamma-Poisson-Factorisation (BGGPF) (Zhou et al., 2012) Asym-NARM works on di-corrected relationship networks with node attributes, which are integrated in a similar way to Sym-NARM. Figure 2 shows the generative process. Here, the latent counting matrix X is factored as X-Poi matrix, whereby the attributes of the node are referred to as factor loading matrix or factor score matrix.

sections.heading: 2.3. Incorporating Hierarchical Node Attributes
sections.text: Relational networks can be associated with hierarchical ancillary information (Hu et al., 2016a). Suppose, for example, that in a patent citation network, patents can be labeled with the code of the International Patent Classification (IPC), which represents a hierarchy of patent categories and subcategories. Suppose the attributes of the second level are stored in a binary matrix F ² {0, 1} L · M, where M is the number of attributes in the second level. Our models can be used to integrate hierarchical node attributes by a simple extension: Replace the hyperparameter µ0 in Equation (6) with µl, k = Hm ² f ² l, m ² k. This extension reflects what is done for attributes of the first level.

sections.heading: 3. Inference with Gibbs Sampling
sections.text: Both Sym-NARM and Asym-NARM enjoy local conjugation, so that the conclusion of all latent variables can be made through closed form Gibbs sampling. In addition, the conclusion only needs to be based on the non-zero entries in Y and F. This section focuses on the sample of hl, k (bk), the key variable in the proposed inclusion of node attributes. The sample of the other latent variables is similar to those in EPM and BGGPF, detailed in (Zhou, 2015; Zhou et al., 2012). sections.heading: 4. Related work
sections.text: Compared to models of node attributes such as NMDR and niMlei, whose methods lead to complicated conclusions, our Sym NARM is much more efficient on large sparse networks, as shown in Table 1.The model most closely related to our Asym NARM theme, which also extends the BGGPF algorithm, is SSI-PF. But it uses gamma additivity to construct the state of node factor loads with the sum of attribute factor loads. Our model has several advantages over SSI-PF: (1) Deriving Gibbs sampling from SSI-PF requires that each column of node factor loads be normalized (Eq. (18)), limiting the application of SSI-PF to other models such as EPM, which is an unnormalized model. (2) Represented in Table 1, Asym NARM, superordinate MARM models.

sections.heading: 5. Experiments
sections.text: In this section, we evaluate Sym-NARM and Asym-NARM with a series of link prediction tasks on 10 real relational datasets of different sizes and types of node attributes. We compare our models with current relational models and show that our models outperform competitors on these datasets in terms of link prediction performance and runtime per iteration. To quantitatively analyze the models, we give the average range below the curve of both receiver operating characteristics (AUC-ROC) and precision recall (AUC-PR). In addition, we perform qualitative analyses by comparing the link probabilities estimated by the comparison models.

sections.heading: 5.1. Link Prediction on Undirected Networks
sections.text: For the link prediction task on undirected network data, we compared our Sym-NARM with two models that do not take into account node attributes, EPM (Zhou, 2015), a state of art relationship model, and iMMM (Koutsourelakis & Eliassi wheel, 2008), a non-parametric version of MMSB, and two node attribute models, niMM (Fan et al., 2016), a non-parametric relationship model that was shown to NMDR (Kim et al., 2012), and DMRMSB, our extension to MMSB using the Dirichlet Multinomial Regression, 2012). SymNAMR was implemented at the top of the EPM code and we used the code from the original authors for EPM and niMM. iMMMMMMMM al.

sections.heading: 5.1.1. EXPERIMENTAL SETTINGS
sections.text: For each data set, we varied the training data from 10% to 90% and used the rest in the test. To generate five random splits, we used the code in the EPM package (Zhou, 2015), which splits a network in terms of its nodes. Reported AUC-ROC / PR values were averaged over the five splits. We used the standard hyperparameter settings for EPM, niMM and iMMM contained in the published code. For our Sym NARM, we set the size of µ0 = 1 for each data set and all other hyperparameters the same as in EPM. Note that the models are not parametric models in comparison with DMR-MSB. For Sym-NARM and EPM, we set the truncation level large enough for each data set: Kmax = 50, 100, 256 for Lazega-Cowork, Facebook-ego and NIPS12, DIPS12.

sections.heading: 5.1.2. RESULTS
sections.text: Overall, our Sym-NARM model performs significantly better than niMM, iMMM and DMR-MMSB on all datasets and EPM on 3 datasets (except Facebook ego with large training portions). Interestingly, the performance of EPM on Facebook ego gradually approaches ours when more than 30% of training data is used. Note that Facebook ego is much denser than the others, meaning that the network information itself may be rich enough for EPM to reconstruct the network and the node attributes to contribute less. However, in general, when relational data is highly incomplete (with less training data), our model can achieve improved link prediction performance. To illustrate how page information helps, we compared our model qualitatively with EPM and node attributes by estimating the link probabilities on NIPS234.

sections.heading: 5.2. Link Prediction on Directed Networks
sections.text: Here we compared our Asym-NARM (implemented in MATLAB on top of the BGGPF code) with two models that do not take into account node attributes, BGGPF (Zhou et al., 2012) and iMMM, and three node attributes models, niMM, SSIPF (Hu et al., 2016a) and DMR-MSB. We used the following four datasets: • Lazega Consulting: This dataset is a directed network with 892 links of consulting relationship between the lawyers. The node attributes are the same as in Lazega Cowork. • Citeseer: This dataset contains a citations network with 2http: / / linqs.umiacs.

sections.heading: 5.2.1. EXPERIMENTAL SETTINGS
sections.text: For fair comparison, we generated training / test data with the code of the SSI-PF package, which splits a network in terms of its linkages. We used the default hyperparameter settings of BGGPF, SSI-PF, and niMM provided by the original authors. Kmax was set to 50 for Lazega Consulting and 200 for all three datasets (such as (Hu et al., 2016a). For our Asym NARM, we used a total of 1,500 MCMC iterations and the last 500 samples to calculate the AUC-ROC / PR values. Since Citeseer, Cora, and Aminer are already too large for niMM, iMMM, and DMR-MR-Laza results, we only reported on their computing power in a reasonable time.

sections.heading: 5.2.2. RESULTS
sections.text: Figure 5a shows that Asym-NARM achieves better AUC-ROC / PR results on Lazega advice in most educational settings than models that do not consider node attributes, demonstrating the usefulness of node attributes. In the other three datasets, we used different attribute sets to investigate how different attributes affect the performance of Asym-NARM and SSI-PF (indicated by "-l"), but the gap between SSI-PF and our model widens when the words are used as attributes (indicated by "-w"). In Cora, SSI-PF approaches our citeseer with attributes (indicated by "-l"), with the gap between SSI-PF and our model widening when the words are used as attributes (indicated by "-w").

sections.heading: 5.3. Link Prediction with Hierarchical Node Attributes
sections.text: Here we used two sets of data with hierarchical node attributes: (1) Cora-here: a citation network with 1712 papers and 6308 links extracted from the original Cora dataset 3. The papers are labeled with one of 63 subsections (first level) and each subsection belongs to one of 10 primary areas (second level), such as "machine learning in artificial intelligence" and "memory management in operating systems." (2) Patent-here: a citation network with 1461 patents and 2141 links from the National Bureau of Economic Research, where the hierarchical code of the International Patent Classification (IPC) of a patent is used as attributes.

sections.heading: 5.4. Running Time
sections.text: In this section we compare the runtime of the directional network models (all implemented in MATLAB and running on a desktop with 3.40 GHz CPU and 16 GB RAM), using 80% training data, the runtime for Asym-NARM, SSI-PF and niMM on Aminer with different node attributes is shown in Table 2. Note: DMR-MMSB was not terminated with "Authors" and "All" due to our computing resources. Asym-NARM is about 10 times faster than SSI-PF with all attributes and about 3https: / / people.cs.umass.edu / mccallum / data.html2 times faster with the designations. Asym-NARM is therefore more efficient, especially with large attributes, which supports complexity analysis in Table 1.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: As a summary of the experiments, Asym / Sym-NARM achieved better link prediction performance with faster inference. While EPM, a non-node attribute model, performed well on nearly complete networks, it deteriorated with less training data. NiMM and DMR-MMSB, extensions to MMSB with the logistical-normal transformation, achieved similar results to Sym-NARM, but scaled inefficiently. SSI-PF was not as good in terms of performance and scalability in the presented cases with flat and hierarchical attributes as Asym-NARM, and it was less effective with a larger number of attributes. Therefore, NARM is a comparatively simple but effective and efficient method of incorporating node attributes, including hierarchical attributes, for relational models with Poisson probability. This results in improved link prediction and matrix completion for less complete data with both our link attributes and with large network input capabilities.

referenceMentions.context: Relational learning from network data, particularly with probabilistic methods, has gained a wide range of applications such as social network analysis (Xiang et al., 2010), recommender systems (Gopalan et al.
, 2016b), and bioinformatics (Huopaniemi et al., 2010).

There have been many Bayesian extensions of these two methods, relaxing the assumptions and/or introducing extra components, such as the Infinite Relational Model (IRM) (Kemp et al., 2006), the mixture membership stochastic block model (MMSB) (Airoldi et al.
, 2006), the mixture membership stochastic block model (MMSB) (Airoldi et al., 2008), and the non-parametric latent feature models (NLFM) (Miller et al.
, 2008), and the non-parametric latent feature models (NLFM) (Miller et al., 2009).

One extreme case is the cold-start problem (Lin et al., 2013; Sedhain et al., 2014; Zhang & Wang, 2015), where a node has no observed links, making suggestion of links for that node even more challenging.

As an extension of MMSB, the Non-parametric Meta-data Dependent Relational (NMDR) model (Kim et al., 2012) incorporates attributes into the mixed-membership distribution of each node with the logistic-normal transform, which results in non-conjugacy for inference.
Fan et al. (2016) further developed this idea in the Node information Involved Mixture Membership model (niMM), where side information is integrated in a conjugate way.
Several recent methods (Gopalan et al., 2014a; Acharya et al., 2015; Hu et al., 2016a) extend PF with side information using the additivity of the Poisson and gamma distributions/processes.

The description of the four datasets used is given below: • Lazega-cowork: This dataset (Lazega, 2001) contains 378 links of the co-work relationship among 71 attorneys.
• NIPS234: This is a co-author network of the 234 authors with 598 links extracted from NIPS 1-17 conferences (Zhou, 2015).

Kmax was set to 50 on Lazega-advice and 200 (same as (Hu et al., 2016a)) on all the other three datasets. For our Asym-NARM, we set μ0 = 1 and the other hyper-parameters the same as those used in (Zhou et al., 2012; Hu et al., 2016a). Following the suggestion of Hu et al. (2016a), we used 1500 MCMC iterations in total and the last 500 samples to compute the AUC-ROC/PR scores.

metadata.abstractText: Relational data are usually highly incomplete in practice, which inspires us to leverage side information to improve the performance of community detection and link prediction. This paper presents a Bayesian probabilistic approach that incorporates various kinds of node attributes encoded in binary form in relational models with Poisson likelihood. Our method works flexibly with both directed and undirected relational networks. The inference can be done by efficient Gibbs sampling which leverages sparsity of both networks and node attributes. Extensive experiments show that our models achieve the stateof-the-art link prediction results, especially with highly incomplete relational data.
